The structure of ice II is also important for understanding the structure of the hydrate, which is a common form of mineral in the ocean. The structure of the hydrate is also important for understanding the structure of the mineral, which is the main component of the Earth’s crust.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum mechanics. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our characterization is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. We hope that it will be useful to researchers in the field.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause disease in a variety of hosts. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme reduction in gene content and genome size. This study provides insights into the molecular basis of the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. One of the hallmarks of this disease is the dysregulation of the immune system, which leads to the activation of the antiviral immune response. However, in some patients, the immune system is not able to control the infection, and the disease becomes severe. In this study, we show that the virus is able to block the activation of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2.

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase dramatically. These results have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices, and for the millions of people living in extreme poverty.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of overlap between species’ diets was greater than expected by chance, and that the degree of overlap was correlated with the degree of similarity in the proportion of grass consumption. These results suggest that the coexistence of large mammalian herbivores in the savanna is driven by the partitioning of the same resources, rather than by competition for the same resources. These findings have implications for our understanding of the drivers of biodiversity in the savanna biome. (Abridged)

We surveyed more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States about their experiences with the COVID-19 crisis. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and many more expect to be in the future. Many businesses expect to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of pollution in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, and that the majority of the plastic debris is concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This accumulation is mostly due to the selective removal of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic debris by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris in the ocean, and is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. The origin of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in science. The age of the Solar System is known to be 4.57 Ga, but the origin of the material that formed the Solar System is still unknown. We determined the age of presolar grains, which are the seeds of the Sun, and found that they are older than the Solar System. This result is important for the origin of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is a key factor in the success of all species that practice allonursing. We show that the practice of allonursing is associated with increased reproductive output, and that this increase is due to the increased availability of resources to the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects multiple brain regions and is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of α-syn that is known to be neurotoxic. In addition, VX-765 was able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of PLP-SYN mice. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for a wide range of functions. It is a highly specialized cell layer that is able to communicate with other cells in the body. This communication is essential for the endothelium to control the functions it is responsible for. In this study, we have used a variety of methods to study the communication between endothelial cells. We have found that the communication between endothelial cells is highly efficient and can be used to control the functions of the endothelium. This study has important implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing treatments for diseases that affect the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The COVIDcast API is available for download at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api. This paper provides a detailed description of the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and decision makers in the fight against COVID-19.

Potassium channels are a large family of proteins that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. They are also involved in a number of diseases, such as epilepsy, heart disease, and muscle weakness. In this study, we have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. These findings will help us to understand the function of potassium channels and to develop new therapeutic strategies for diseases involving these proteins.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not well understood. One aspect of the gut microbiome that is poorly understood is the role of the anaerobic fungi that live in the gut. This study shows that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. We show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes an individual to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. In addition, we identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, which is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to program mechanical devices to realize any desired response is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy to design and manufacture function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design and manufacture a wide range of devices with complex and programmable responses for a variety of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of mechanical devices. It also provides a promising approach for the design of soft robotics.
The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 microRNA pathway. Here we show that the let-7 pathway is also involved in the regulation of the timing of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which is highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that the inhibition of SREBP1 or the induction of ferroptosis sensitize cancer cells to ferroptosis, and that this combination results in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings provide a rationale for the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study shows that the use of these drugs is associated with the development of heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem, which is the focus of a recent policy proposal, is not a panacea for the conservation of older forests. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. This will be a challenge, as the early-seral ecosystem is expanding on federal land.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. View Full-Text

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data, compared to popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used for a wide range of problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The results provide a unique perspective on the influence of climate variability on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock, which is one of the most diverse freshwater ecosystems on Earth. The results have implications for the evolution of the African Rift System and the formation of the Great Rift Valley. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime can have important consequences for sleep, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a short period of global climate change that occurred 12,900 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the boundary. We show that the osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the sites of the Younger Dryas boundary are consistent with a terrestrial origin. In addition, we report the discovery of rare 1.5-Ga rocks in the YDB sites, which are consistent with the source of the microspherules. These findings support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Read more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is largely unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for the induction of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that, in general, larger populations did not enhance CCE. However, we did find that, in some cases, larger populations did enhance CCE, but only under certain specific conditions. These findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the design of cultural evolution experiments. They also have implications for the design of human societies, which may be more effective at enhancing CCE than technological populations. This article is protected by copyright. Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and the seventh leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for Alzheimer’s disease. These data put APOE central to Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify Alzheimer’s disease risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere of iron that is about 1,700 km in radius. It is the only solid sphere in the solar system. The formation of the inner core is one of the most important unsolved problems in geophysics. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, which is different from the conventional view. This mechanism provides a key factor in solving the long-standing paradox of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is blunted in marijuana abusers. This blunted reactivity may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex cognitive skill we have. How the human brain processes language is therefore a fundamental question in cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks can be used to understand the human brain’s processing of language.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is due to the use of standard optimization algorithms, which are not stable. We introduce a new algorithm, which we prove is stable, and we show that it is fast. We also establish a theory of stability for neural networks, which we use to prove that the number of layers needed to achieve a given accuracy is finite. Our results have implications for the design of neural networks and for the development of scientific computing with deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is currently in the midst of a heated debate about the role of people’s inability to understand exponential growth in the spread of the disease. This debate is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its critical design flaws, the study is often cited as a proof of the existence of the phenomenon it set out to study. This article discusses the flaws of the experiment and the implications of this case study for the scientific community.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with the more severe form of the disease, and found that it is very similar to the genome of M. leprae, which is associated with the milder form of the disease. This suggests that the two bacteria are closely related and that they have been able to maintain many of the same functions for thousands of years. This finding has implications for our understanding of leprosy and the evolution of bacteria in general. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also central to the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. However, the entanglement dynamics is a very difficult problem to solve. We show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed millions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on a live attenuated virus. This study describes the development of a vaccine based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and the spike protein can be presented to the immune system. The vaccine is protective in a relevant animal model. This study provides a promising candidate for mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague and the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of the disease. It also provides a framework for studying the history of disease transmission in the past.

The brain is the most complex organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn and adapt to our environment. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key factor in the evolution of intelligence. The brain is not a single organ but consists of many different types of cells, each of which is responsible for a specific function. We can therefore study the evolution of brain function by looking at the evolution of the number and type of brain cells.

TRAP1 is a molecular chaperone that is found predominantly in mitochondria. It is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the utility of current TRAP1 inhibitors is questionable because they cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, two proteins that are closely related. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the regulation of actin dynamics. It is a key regulator of the formation of stress fibers and lamellipodia, and is involved in the formation of the actin cortex, which is important for cell motility. In this work, we show that ADF can sever actin filaments, and that this process is enhanced by mechanical stress. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our results. This model may be important for understanding the role of ADF in cell motility.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other beverages. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and heterogeneous way, suggesting that the island was settled by multiple waves of people. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the study of the human history of the Indian Ocean. It will also be useful for the study of the human history of the African continent, as Madagascar is a unique window into the past of Africa. View Full-Text

We show that the emotional content of Facebook posts influences the emotions of people who view the posts. This work has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for the study of emotional contagion in the real world.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been shown to impact the rate of protein synthesis. However, the impact of a single modification on the rate of protein synthesis has not been studied. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA can impact the rate of protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The reason for the high incidence of rhinovirus infection in the winter is not known. One possibility is that rhinovirus replicates better at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. This study shows that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This mechanism is important for the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity.

The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global problem. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is based on the analysis of 838 peer-reviewed studies. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the proliferation of large dams, and the solutions that are needed. We propose a set of innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the immune response in AD is thought to be primarily driven by microglial cells, which are the brain’s resident immune cells. Here, we show that neurons, rather than microglia, are the primary source of the proinflammatory response in AD. This finding has important implications for the development of new therapies for AD, as it suggests that targeting the immune response in neurons may be a more effective strategy for treating the disease.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore predates the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of the domestic chicken and its spread across the world. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the knowledge of the steps involved in the process is important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell and for the development of new drugs.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the mechanism by which this occurs is not fully understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap from Np4-capped RNAs is also activated by stress, and that it has the ability to deprotect Np4-capped RNAs.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main player in the resolution of sepsis, it is also the main target of the inflammatory response. We show that arginine, a key molecule in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, the metabolic product of arginine, is more effective than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of arginine in the immune system and its potential as a therapeutic target in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to improve our understanding of the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems with no external control parameter can maintain a critical state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe the connection between our model and pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be changed by strain. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed from a semiconductor to a metal by strain engineering. This finding will open up new possibilities for the design of devices and applications based on diamond. It will also provide a new perspective on the properties of diamond and other materials. This work will be of interest to researchers in materials science, physics, and engineering. (Show more)

This study describes the structure, antifungal activity, and mode of action of a unique class of cysteine-rich peptides. The structure of the 36-residue peptide, NCR044, was solved by NMR spectroscopy. It exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It also showed strong cell wall binding and induced reactive oxygen species in germlings. The mode of action of the peptide was revealed by time-lapse microscopy. This study provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this class of peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and yet our understanding of the molecular basis of this interface is limited. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a reservoir of proteins that support the viability of sperm, suggesting that the female reproductive tract may serve as a source of proteins that support the development of the embryo. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that plays a critical role in the blood clotting process. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF, which is important for binding to platelets, can be switched between two states by force. This provides a mechanism for the fast binding observed in the presence of platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential for human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive database of viruses associated with humans, and shows that viruses play a significant role in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is complex and difficult to be observed. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has changed over geological time, and the mechanisms for this change are not fully understood. We show that the temperature of the surface of the Earth was higher in the past than previously thought.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow. They are also the targets of many drugs. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for the regulation of many physiological and pathological processes. However, the relationship between the activation and inactivation of ion channels is still not fully understood.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell in which it replicates. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a specific antigen on the parasite surface to bind to a specific receptor on the RBC surface. This interaction alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve performance. In this work, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal by applying strain. This finding opens up new possibilities for the design of devices and materials based on diamond. The results of this work can be used to improve the performance of devices based on diamond, and to develop new applications based on this material. The findings of this work are expected to have a significant impact on the field of materials science and engineering. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza virus infection. We found that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in the resolution of inflammation. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus disease. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often assumed to be a tree of nested phrases, but there is no direct evidence for this hypothesis. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to identify the structure of language. This parser is located in the superior temporal and inferior frontal regions of the left hemisphere.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer, and thus, it is a major area of research. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. This is a major finding, as it shows that the two forms of Axin are not only redundant but also that they are functionally similar. This finding may be useful in the future for the development of therapeutics for cancer and other diseases.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that drive overeating are not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is mediated by a specific circuit in the hypothalamus.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in barley and model rhizobia, which will allow the delivery of biologically fixed nitrogen to cereal crops in a manner that is specific to the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work will allow the development of a sustainable agriculture that is free of the use of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people worldwide. Vaccines are the most effective way to contain the pandemic, but the high cost of current vaccines may limit their global access. We report a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which is the target of the virus for entry into cells, that is well-suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the human receptor, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 variant used in current vaccines. The engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD can be used to develop a cost-effective vaccine for global access. This work provides a potential solution to the global pandemic. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor in children. In the majority of cases, the underlying genetic alterations are not understood. In this study, we identified a set of genes that are involved in the development of neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is one of the most dramatic events in the history of the genus. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a unique perspective on the evolution of the pathogen during this critical period. Our results show that the pathogen was not only able to adapt to a new host, but also to a new vector, and that the pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps that led to its emergence as a deadly pathogen. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its relationship to its hosts and vectors. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. In addition, HM predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of agriculture and the global carbon cycle. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on native grassland soils can have a significant impact on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the vulnerability of humans to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to search for viruses of interest. SpillOver is a living database that can be updated to reflect the latest scientific evidence and public health interventions. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often thought to be a visual cue for pollinators, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is a convergently evolved adaptation, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a unique example of convergent evolution in the evolution of nectar color. (Show more)

We present a study of a group of women who lived in southern Germany at the end of the 5th century AD. The analysis of their genomes indicates that they were not only of northern European but also of eastern European origin. This is an example of female-biased migration, which is a rare phenomenon in the archaeological record. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a pathogen that currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and bat coronaviruses. They also suggest that the use of DPP4

This study is a proof of concept for the use of mNGS in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a febrile population. We also show that the use of mNGS can help identify the presence of a large national outbreak of chikungunya virus. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using mNGS in a resource-scarce setting and the potential of mNGS in the early detection of emerging pathogens.

The human cell is constantly replicating its genome, a process that requires the faithful duplication of DNA. This process is carried out by the DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) enzyme, which is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and provides a foundation for future studies on the role of pol δ in human disease.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we report the first successful in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of neighborhoods over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. We expect that our method will be useful for urban planners, geographers, and urban sociologists.

COVID-19 is a new disease, and the treatment is still in the process of development. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, can improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a reference for the clinical treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is poorly understood. Here we report the existence of a copper-binding natural product in fungi, and demonstrate that this product has a role in copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal growth.

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, which is a rare mineral on Earth. It is a common mineral in the Martian crust, but its presence on Mars has been inferred from X-ray diffraction analyses of rocks and soils. This is the first detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from the surface of Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock provides new insights into the early history of the Martian crust and the evolution of the Martian climate.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural and forestry crops, and the economic impact of late-spring frosts is estimated to be in the billions of dollars. However, the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of late-spring frosts is linked to the geographic distribution of the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees. Our findings can be used to inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process is dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. These results have important implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease mechanism and to screen for therapeutics. This method will be useful for ALS research and for the study of other neurodegenerative diseases.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of the pathogen. We also show that the antifreeze glycoprotein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall, which alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector and may lead to the development of strategies to control the transmission of human pathogens. The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a new early member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the changes in one part of the system can affect the rest of the system. In this paper, we show that the changes in water vapor in the stratosphere can affect the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can be used to camouflage the animal in its environment. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the color of the animal is determined by a protein that binds biliverdin, a molecule that is responsible for the green color of the environment.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with the development of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is associated with the development of cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production of tissue-thin parchment did not necessarily require the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics depend on an accurate and precise age model. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The intestinal epithelium is the most important barrier of the body, and its homeostasis is essential for the survival of the host. However, the intestinal epithelium is easily damaged, leading to the development of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in the intestinal epithelium leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in the open conformation, which is the most infectious, and in the closed conformation, which is the most prevalent in the current circulating virus population. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation. This finding may help to explain the increased infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We project that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, and a decline of 0.87 y at age 65 y, for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections highlight the need for public health interventions to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and other causes of death. They also underscore the need for policies that address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as materials science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we propose a modified version of the Mulliken electronegativity scale. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict the behavior of chemical elements under pressure. This work is of interest to the chemistry and materials science communities.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of global fire activity, and that this is likely to continue in the future. However, we also show that the effects of fire on climate are more complex, and that the trajectory of global warming may be reduced by up to 10 y by changes in fire activity. This is important for the global carbon cycle, as well as for the services that fire provides to society.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal–microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host signals the provision of a nutrient, and the consequences of such a signal for the symbiont, are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of chitin, a polymeric glycan, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria. We also show that the chitin is provided and metabolized only at night, when the symbiotic organ is actively producing light. These results suggest that the timing of nutrient provision may be a general strategy for regulating the activities of symbiotic microbes. This article is protected by copyright. Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward the goal of being able to analyze text data in a way that is analogous to analyzing data in other domains.

The Black Death, which killed millions of people in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The origin of this disease is still debated, but it is generally assumed that it was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks were the driving force behind the reintroduction of the disease into European harbors, rather than a single introduction of Yersinia pestis. Our results provide evidence for a series of climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This suggests that the Black Death was not introduced into Europe by a single event, but rather by multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a long period of adaptation. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the history of the plague pandemic.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem, and their loss has been shown to have significant effects on the ecosystem. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of targets for the treatment of AML is therefore of great importance. In this study, we identified IL1RAP as a target for the treatment of AML. We show that the monoclonal antibody (mAb) targeting IL1RAP has strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. In addition, we generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our study provides a proof of concept for the treatment of AML with an antibody targeting IL1RAP. This study also provides a new strategy for the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth and a heterogeneous distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy people. They also provide a framework for the study of the genomic diversity of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. View Full-Text

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which collects expert assessments of crop status, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to improve the monitoring and management of agricultural production. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor and manage other natural resources.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.
