The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is associated with the loss of a major function, photosynthesis. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to parasitism is associated with a stepwise relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The results of this study provide a quantitative assessment of the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in South Africa. The results show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in South Africa to future anthropogenic emissions. The results are important for the design of adaptation strategies and for the development of climate change scenarios for water resources management. View Full-Text

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the world’s most famous nuclear test site is a unique event. The material, which is a naturally occurring icosahedral quasicrystal, is named “red trinitite” after the color of the material and the historical significance of the site. The discovery of this material provides a unique link between the past and the present, and demonstrates that quasicrystals can be found in the natural world.

The formation of the fifth isoprenoid ring in (bacterio)chlorophyll biosynthesis is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The enzymes that catalyze this reaction have been identified in a variety of organisms, but the mechanism of the reaction has remained elusive. This paper describes the identification of a third class of the enzyme, and the identification of a protein that is a subunit of the enzyme in plants and cyanobacteria.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also known to be involved in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis. However, the mechanisms of neuroinflammation in multiple sclerosis remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was phase specific, and the role of neuroinflammation was dependent on the cell type. We also found that ASK1 was a key regulator of neuroinflammation, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may also provide a new perspective for the development of neuroinflammation-based therapies.

The 2012–2014 California drought is one of the most extreme in the state’s history. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially in California over the past century, and that this increase is due to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The identification of the causal genes and the causal mechanisms is a major challenge. In this study, we identified a converging function of the autism-risk genes in the regulation of behavior.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results have implications for the study of human cognition and behavior, and for the design of news content.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disease of unknown cause. Here, we report a patient with Stormorken syndrome, a disorder of the Ca2+ channel ORAI1, and describe the clinical features of Stormorken syndrome in detail. We also describe a second patient with Stormorken syndrome, who carries a gain-of-function mutation in STIM1. Our results expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the activity of endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires the activity of the protein fusion protein 1. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and the potential for therapeutic strategies to block this process. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX has no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore does not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and thus the cell’s ability to synthesize one-carbon units is critical. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) isozymes, and have shown that it blocks tumor growth. We have also shown that the one-carbon donor, formate, is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition. However, formate is a poor rescue in a cancer cell line with defective glycine import. This finding suggests that the cell’s ability to import glycine is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS, form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics of quantum matter, including the effects of the photonic crystal on the properties of the atoms, and the effects of the atoms on the photonic crystal.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and, in some cases, may have been the first plants to live in aquatic habitats. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from living organisms. However, viruses can persist in the fossil record for millions of years, and ancient viral sequences can provide information about the evolution of viruses that is not available from living organisms. Here we present the oldest known viral sequences, which date back more than 60 thousand years, and show that the evolution of B19V has been slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also provides a unique resource for future studies. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, and shows that it is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not seen for those with a bachelor’s degree. The increase in pain prevalence for those with less education is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The study of the mechanisms of enzymes is often aided by the use of spectroscopic techniques, such as NMR spectroscopy, to characterize the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex. However, the study of the enzyme–substrate complex is often limited by the lack of structural information about the enzyme–cofactor complex. Here, we show how the use of NMR-assisted crystallography can provide this missing structural information, and how it can be used to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex. This detailed picture of the enzyme–substrate complex is key to understanding the reaction pathway and the role of the cofactor in the reaction. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) remains a severe and lethal disease, with a high case fatality rate. There is an urgent need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal–microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which the host signals the provision of a nutrient, and the consequences of such a signal for the symbiont, are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of chitin, a polymeric glycan, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria. We also show that the chitin is provided and metabolized only at night, when the symbiotic organ is actively producing light. These results suggest that the timing of nutrient provision may be a general strategy for regulating the activities of symbiotic microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This paper is about the importance of relationships in schools. It shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a large impact on students’ behavior. It also shows that it is possible to change the mindsets of teachers in large numbers, and that this change can have a large impact on students’ behavior.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is known to be involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcription of a lacZ reporter gene. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of a better understanding of the role of DNA alkylation in human diseases and for the design of novel therapeutic strategies.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. The virus requires spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that sequential proteolysis of the S glycoproteins is required for MERS-CoV infection of human lung-derived cells, but not other cell types. This finding suggests that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a major cause of disease. We show that it is possible to make a large-scale change in the food system by simply changing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering operation. This approach could be used in other sectors to promote more sustainable diets and healthier populations.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we provide a systems-level view of how the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion by six of the most prominent oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS, and how the surfaceome is remodeled by a potent MEK inhibitor. We also provide a view of the glycoproteome, which is the site of covalent modification of the surfaceome by glycosylation. These studies provide a foundation for the discovery of surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. However, the effects of such a policy are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail programs are not likely to have a significant impact on the outcome of elections.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health crisis, and the molecular basis for its severity and rapid spread is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV, which may be important for immune suppression and evasion. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic and may lead to the development of therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1), which in turn leads to an increase in water influx into the astrocytes and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also provide a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important, but we can’t remember them all. So we search for the strongest associations. This is a sensible approach, but it means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant an association that we find. We describe a new way of doing this, based on the idea of “selective inference.” This is a general approach that can be used in many situations, and we illustrate it with examples from regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that it will help people to think about the challenges of big data and complex statistical modeling.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of vascular ECs has been difficult to achieve. Here, we report the development of vascular ECs from human skin fibroblasts using ETV2. This study provides a new approach for the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of a new treatment for vascular disorders. (Show more)
We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentor receptors, and demonstrate that they are essential for the development of a specific type of skin cells.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that the function of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion was critical for the regulation of glucose homeostasis.

Influenza A viruses are the most pathogenic of all RNA viruses. They cause annual epidemics and occasionally severe pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the virus particles. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of the influenza A virus replication cycle. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including flow. However, the mechanisms by which flow regulates the development of atherosclerotic lesions are not fully understood. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the regulation of the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms by which flow regulates the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that people have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropod pests remain elusive. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular basis for the use of natural repellents in pest control and the conservation of biodiversity. It also offers a new perspective on the evolution of insect–plant interaction. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus has been associated with neurological complications and birth defects. The mechanisms of infection and the factors that determine the severity of the disease are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma viral load in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can be effective in reducing the peak viral load and shortening the time to undetectable viral load. The results presented here can be used to guide the design of clinical trials and to develop mathematical models for the design of future studies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is pushing the world’s coral reefs to the brink of collapse. We show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication between the host and the microbiota. In this study, we show that the loss of the intestinal epithelium barrier function is associated with the activation of the JNK pathway, which in turn, triggers the growth of intestinal tumors. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for the development of cancer therapies and for the understanding of the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but the response of individual patients to treatment is highly variable. We show that the expression of a receptor, ROR1, is increased in breast cancer patients who respond poorly to chemotherapy. We also show that the expression of ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this attribution is based on a single paleoclimate proxy. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is instead linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high human population density and river discharge. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are the key to achieve high energy density and safety. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. However, in the adult mammalian CNS, this ability is lost. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in regeneration, and it also suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more regenerative than previously thought.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the function of genes. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination activity in a flowering plant, which is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state of the brain is a complex and dynamic process, which is not fully understood. In this study, we used resting metabolic imaging to identify and validate the resting state organization of the human brain. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant resting state network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network deactivation was observed in early Parkinson’s disease, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the resting state of the human brain. They also have implications for the development of new imaging techniques and for the clinical management of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs.

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is of great interest because of the potential of DNA methylation to be a biomarker of the effects of diabetes treatment. We found that DNA methylation at certain loci in blood cells is altered in people with diabetes, and that these alterations persist for several years in the blood of people with diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive form of breast cancer and is difficult to treat. We show that the tumor-suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and for the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a brain disorder, but the mechanisms involved in the development of the disease are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and in the regulation of the psychological symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit.

We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are more severe than previously thought. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning changes as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. This change in the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is driven by two processes. First, more diverse communities are more likely to contain species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we find a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions play a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the future of the Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in navigation and memory. However, the organization of its neurons is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are not strongly coupled to other cell types, and that they are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings provide a foundation for future studies of the organization of MEC and its role in behavior. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not the only flowering signal in plants. We demonstrate that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the activity of dopamine-producing neurons. The present study shows that dopamine-containing neurons are also affected in a different way. We show that dopamine-containing neurons are affected in a different way. We show that dopamine-containing neurons are affected in a different way.

We are all social creatures, and we all want to feel connected to others. But how do we know when we are? We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and is the primary site of atrial fibrillation. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. We report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in silicon deposition and the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biopesticide to protect rice from insect attack. This study also provides a framework for the development of a sustainable pest management strategy for rice. (Show more)

This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It also reveals a central role of alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and demonstrates that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic substances in the environment. Thus, plants are highly susceptible to toxic substances in the environment. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver functional biomolecules to plants, which can be used to deliver genes for the production of useful compounds.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small and large tributaries in driving coastal nutrient loading is poorly understood. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to Lake Michigan comes from a small number of large tributaries, but that the vast majority of nutrients are dissolved inorganic forms that are more bioavailable. This suggests that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading in coastal areas. Our findings have important implications for the management of nutrient loading in large water bodies worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of the dynamics of complex networks, where the presence of rare combinations of states may be a general feature. It may also be relevant to the study of the dynamics of complex systems in general, where the presence of rare combinations of states may be a general feature.

This paper offers a unique perspective on the mechanisms of action of a class of autoimmune encephalitis. It is a very important paper, and it is a pleasure to be able to include it in this issue of Science.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, and the mechanisms that drive abrupt climate change are still debated. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was driven by a combination of changes in the carbon cycle and the ocean.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire is unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation, but that most certified areas contain little residual forest. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet achieving its potential.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the function of the cell. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that can be used to study the regulation of the exocyst complex.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animal life, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of reproductive success. In this study, we show that the sex of a fish can be determined by a single genetic locus, but that the sex of the same fish can be determined by multiple interacting genetic loci.
The retina is a unique organ in that it is the only tissue in the body that contains iron. This study shows that the presence of iron in the retina can have a negative impact on the retina.

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, and that specialization can be linked to the evolution of separate structures dedicated to prey capture. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the amino acid serine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). We show that this inhibitor blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition in colon cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the impacts of deforestation on people’s health and livelihoods are well documented. However, little is known about the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets, which are a key indicator of nutrition. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, but the increase in weight has also increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, and that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and for the evolution of animal behavior. (Show more)
